subject: Law
title: Rights of Nature
description: A quick win: understand Rights of Nature.

hook.text: A river in New Zealand has the same legal rights as a person. It can sue polluters through its guardians.

buildup.text: Rights of Nature movements grant legal personhood to ecosystems, giving them standing to seek court protection.

discovery.text: Ecuador was the first country to enshrine Rights of Nature in its constitution (2008). Bolivia followed.

twist.text: Critics say nature can't hold rightsâ€”only humans can. Supporters say ecosystems need protection beyond human interests.

climax.text: US cities and tribes have adopted Rights of Nature ordinances. Courts are still deciding whether they hold up.

punchline.text: A river as a legal person. It sounds radicalâ€”until you consider the alternative.
